page.title: 19CROPWELL BUTLER CONSERVATION
page.content: The ecology of this village accords with the mode of life of the inhabit- ants. The arable fields are attractive at all times of the year, farm stock is pleasant & there are many fine indigenous trees, particularly horse- chestnut. Many new trees have been planted by the Parish Council, & in an effort to combine conservation & wild life preservation with commercial farming, one large land owner has planted many thousands of trees, built a lake for both irrigation & environ- mental purposes & returned land to grass from cereals. The grave-yard at Tithby is particularly attractive in Spring when drifts of snowdrops are visible under the oak trees. Footpaths are well maintained due to the vigilance of the Parish Council. At Butler there is discussion about the establishment of a conservation area.
